Situation1: There is a scheduled family gathering on the calendar.
Expectation2: Prepare and maintain financial records accurately.
Situation2: The deadline for closing the books for the month is approaching.
Story: I stared at the calendar on my phone, the bright red circle around Saturday’s date reminding me of the family gathering my daughter had planned weeks ago. My grandson had called me yesterday, his voice bubbling with excitement about showing me his new train set. I promised him I’d be there, and I could already picture his face lighting up when I walked through the door. But as I sat at my desk, the spreadsheets on my computer glared back at me, numbers blurring together. The month-end closing deadline was looming, and the reports weren’t adding up. My manager had sent a reminder this morning: accuracy was critical, and any errors could have serious consequences for the company. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing down on me—my family expecting my presence, my job demanding my focus. My heart ached at the thought of disappointing my grandson, but my mind raced with the fear of letting my team down. I sat there, torn, unable to silence the competing voices in my head, knowing I had to choose but wishing I didn’t have to.
